entries.orthography: Runes (futhorc) then Latin alphabet; letters like þ, ð, æ
entries.pronunciation: Highly inflected; vowel length distinctive; consonant clusters complex
entries.grammar: Strong vs weak verbs; case system; three genders; dual pronouns
entries.phoneticExample: Hwæt! We Gardena in geardagum… / hwæt we ˈɡɑrdɛna in ˈjɛɑrdaɣum…
entries.notes: Germanic language heavily inflected; limited Latin/French influence before Norman Conquest.

entries.usage: Literature, legal, administrative documents; oral speech
entries.orthography: Latin alphabet; inconsistent spelling; French influence
entries.pronunciation: Vowel shifts begin (Middle English Vowels); consonants simplify
entries.grammar: Loss of most inflections; case system simplified; gender mostly lost
entries.notableTexts: Chaucer's Canterbury Tales, Pearl, Sir Gawain and the Green Knight
entries.phoneticExample: Whan that Aprille with his shoures soote… / wan θat aˈprilːe wið hɪs ˈʃuːres ˈsoːtə…
entries.notes: French influence dominant after Norman Conquest; regional dialects varied.

entries.usage: Printing press literature, official documents, poetry, drama
entries.orthography: Latin alphabet standardized gradually; spelling varies
entries.pronunciation: Great Vowel Shift ongoing; consonants largely modern
entries.grammar: Verb endings simplify; auxiliary verbs more common; word order stabilizes
entries.notableTexts: Shakespeare, King James Bible, Spenser's Faerie Queene
entries.phoneticExample: To be, or not to be: that is the question… / tə bi, ɔːr nɒt tə bi: ðæt ɪz ðə ˈkwɛstʃən…
entries.notes: Transition to modern spelling and grammar; increased literacy and standardization.

entries.usage: All domains: spoken, literary, scientific, official
entries.orthography: Latin alphabet; standardized spelling; diacritics rare
entries.grammar: Analytic language; word order fixed; auxiliary verbs for tense/aspect
entries.phoneticExample: Hello, how are you? / həˈloʊ haʊ ɑr ju?
entries.notes: Global spread; standard British and American forms; English as international lingua franca.

entries.orthography: 24 letters; pitch accent; diacritics: acute, grave, circumflex, rough/smooth breathing
entries.pronunciation: β = /b/, γ = /g/, δ = /d/, θ = /tʰ/, φ = /pʰ/, χ = /kʰ/; long vs short vowels mattered
entries.grammar: Complex morphology; optative mood; dual number; multiple tenses
entries.phoneticExample: Ὅμηρος: ἄνδρα μοι ἔννεπε, Μοῦσα… / ˈhomɛːros ˈandra moi ˈennepe, ˈmusa…
entries.notes: Classical Greek forms the basis of most later Greek scholarship and literature.

entries.usage: Common spoken and written Greek; biblical texts; Hellenistic literature
entries.pronunciation: Shift toward stress accent; β → /v/ begins; γ softening
entries.grammar: Simplified morphology; optative less common; dative merges with genitive
entries.notableTexts: Septuagint, New Testament, early Hellenistic poetry
entries.phoneticExample: Ἐν ἀρχῇ ἦν ὁ λόγος / en arˈkʰɛː ɛːn ho ˈloɡos
entries.notes: Lingua franca of the eastern Mediterranean after Alexander the Great.

entries.orthography: Diacritics largely abandoned; monotonic writing emerges later
entries.pronunciation: Stress accent; β = /v/, γ = /ɣ/, δ = /ð/; vowels simplified
entries.notes: Transition period bridging Koine and Modern Greek; strong liturgical influence.

entries.usage: Spoken language, modern literature, official Greek
entries.orthography: 24 letters; monotonic system with tonos (´); sigma has final form ς
entries.pronunciation: Stress accent; η, ι, υ, ει, οι → /i/; consonants: φ = /f/, θ = /θ/, χ = /x/, γ = /ɣ/
entries.grammar: Simplified morphology; modern tense and mood system
entries.notes: Standard Modern Greek based on Demotic, official since 1976.

entries.grammar: Complex verb endings, case particles, honorific forms in nascent form
entries.phoneticExample: 天皇の命 / Ama-no-kami no mikoto / ama no kami no mikoto
entries.notes: Earliest attested form of Japanese; influenced by Chinese in writing.

entries.pronunciation: Eight-vowel system reduces; pitch accent develops
entries.grammar: Refined verb conjugations; keigo (polite forms) develop; auxiliary verbs stabilize
entries.phoneticExample: いづれの御時にか / izure no on toki ni ka / idzure no on toki ni ka
entries.notes: Language of Heian court literature; literary style differs from spoken language.

entries.orthography: Modern kana orthography begins; kanji usage expands
entries.pronunciation: Seven-vowel system; pitch accent begins approximating modern forms
entries.grammar: Verb endings simplified; honorifics system standardized
entries.phoneticExample: 奥の細道 / Oku no Hosomichi / oku no hosomichi
entries.notes: Transition toward modern language; Edo-period vernacular emerges.

entries.usage: Spoken and written language, literature, media, official
entries.orthography: Modern kanji, hiragana, katakana; romanization used academically
entries.pronunciation: Modern pitch accent; standard Tokyo dialect phonology
entries.grammar: Simplified morphology; modern verb and adjective conjugation; keigo system standardized
entries.notes: Contemporary Japanese; official standard based on Tokyo dialect; spoken and written converge.
